text:
GÜLER SABANCI: He had
six sons, my grandfather.
No daughters.

The first three
sons have started

working right after
the secondary school,
including my father.

But he insisted
that the last three
had to go to the best schools.

And the last
three-- we call them

the first group, first brothers,
first group of brothers,

and the second
group of brothers.

And the first group of
brothers, of course,

was in apprenticeship with their
father, and he trusted them.

He gave them different
responsibilities.

And after years passed,
we see that he actually

has given them responsibilities,
accountabilities, according
to their real capabilities.

SPEAKER: So he knew
them very well.

GÜLER SABANCI: And
so he knew them,

and he tested them
during the period.
He was a good coach.
He was a good coach, I think.

SPEAKER: Was he demanding
with his children?

GÜLER SABANCI: Demanding,
motivating, and testing.

And so I had my small
share of that also.
SPEAKER: With him?

GÜLER SABANCI: Further
in the interview,

you will ask me why I
love so much the industry.

Because I think it
was he who planted it.
I was three years old.
He took me to the factory.
